Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Associations between Symbiotic Bacterial Communities and Infection by an Emerging Fungal Pathogen: Distinguishing Cause from Correlation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Summary: Symbiotic microflora (communities of microbes living on or in multicellular organisms) are important players in the health of multicellular organisms. Variation in the microbial species inhabiting the human body has been linked to differences in susceptibility to diseases from obesity to salmonellosis. In contrast, little is known about the microflora of non-human animals or plants. This study assesses how symbiotic microflora affect disease resistance in the mountain yellow-legged frog (Rana sierrae). Previous results show that differences in the microbial communities found on the skin of these frogs are linked to variation in the severity of chytridiomycosis, a disease of the skin that results from infection by the fungal pathogen, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis. The current study investigates the causes responsible for these patterns by experimentally manipulating the microbial communities living on the skin of R. sierrae, subsequently exposing frogs to B. dendrobatidis, and measuring resulting disease progression. This experiment addresses three questions: (1) Which factors control the identity of microbes that make up the normal microflora? (2) Do differences in the species composition of the microflora affect the ability of the frogs to resist infection by B. dendrobatidis? (3) When infection by B. dendrobatidis does occur, does it disturb the symbiotic microbial community, leading to changes in the microbial species that make up the normal microflora? Results will advance fundamental understanding of the factors shaping symbiotic microbial communities and their importance in health and disease.

Broader impacts: Amphibians worldwide are undergoing mass declines and extinctions, and chytridiomycosis is one of the greatest threats to these animals. This study is relevant to the management of chytridiomycosis and the conservation of amphibians. Laboratory and field trials are currently underway to test the use of probiotic bacteria to protect amphibians from the disease, yet basic knowledge about the symbiotic communities naturally occurring on threatened amphibians and their function in disease resistance is limited. Such knowledge will be improved by this study. In addition, this project provides a critical training opportunity for the graduate student and for an undergraduate assistant who will gain research experience through integral participation in the study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animals and humans are inhabited by vast communities of microbes, referred to as symbiotic microbial communities or the microbiome. For example, the human body contains far more bacterial cells than human cells.  Symbiotic microbes are increasingly recognized to play important roles in the development and health of their multicellular hosts. For example, recent studies in related fields have shown that the bacteria inhabiting humans affect development (e.g. of the gut and immune systems) as well as predisposition to generally non-infectious health problems such as obesity, allergies and asthma.  In comparison, the interaction between symbiotic microbes and most infectious diseases is not well understood.  Filling this gap in scientific knowledge is important for two reasons: First, the microbiome may affect susceptibility to infectious diseases.  Second, the opposite type of interaction is possible, in which infectious pathogens disturb the normal healthy microbiome when they infect a host, and this can lead to further health problems, given the already-demonstrated importance of microbial symbionts in host health and development. These processes are potentially important to human health, but also for efforts to conserve global biodiversity.  This project studied the interaction between symbiotic bacterial communities and the infectious fungal pathogen Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, which infects the skin of amphibians (frogs, toads, and salamanders) and causes a potentially lethal disease (chytridiomycosis). The project examined the taxonomic and phylogenetic composition (i.e., the types of bacteria present) of the amphibian skin microbiome and aimed to understand how the skin microbiome interacts with the fungal pathogen. A specific aim was to test if infection by the pathogen causes changes in the bacterial community, a question that had not been previously addressed in the scientific literature.  This study addressed that question through an experiment that enabled distinction of cause from effect, which is important because correlations between pathogen infection and variation in the microbiome can be caused by the microbiome affecting susceptibility to infection or, vice versa, the pathogen affecting the microbiome. The results of this project clearly demonstrated that infection with the B. dendrobatidis causes changes to the bacterial community on the skin of frogs.  Several bacterial species normally present on the skin of these frogs show drastic changes in their abundance when frogs become infected with the pathogen. The results from this relatively small study highlight the importance of further research to understand variation in the amphibian skin microbiome, its sensitivity to disturbance, and its role in disease resistance.

The results of this project are important to the management of chytridiomycosis, which has caused the extinction of amphibian species and threatens many others, including Rana sierrae, the species studied here. Currently there are no broadly effective methods to curb the decline of wild amphibians due to chytridiomycosis. The application of probiotic bacteria to the skin of amphibians to increase their resistance to the disease has shown some promise in laboratory trials, but better understanding of the stability of the microbiome in the face of pathogen infection is important for the efficacy of such interventions.  This project showed that the amphibian skin microbiome is highly sensitive to disturbance by infection by B. dendrobatidis. This result may help explain why probiotic treatments for chytridiomycosis are not always effective.  Further examination of the sensitivity and stability of specific bacterial species in the face of B. dendrobatidis infection can improve the development of probiotics to manage or prevent the disease...
